verse.arabic_text: يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا كُتِبَ عَلَيْكُمُ الصِّيَامُ كَمَا كُتِبَ عَلَى الَّذِينَ مِن قَبْلِكُمْ لَعَلَّكُمْ تَتَّقُونَ
verse.translation: O you who have believed, decreed upon you is fasting as it was decreed upon those before you that you may become righteous.

theme_question.correct: The divine command for fasting to achieve piety (Taqwa).

educational_notes.verse_context: This verse marks the divine commandment for Muslims to fast during the month of Ramadan. It appears within a section of Surah Al-Baqarah that outlines various laws and regulations for the nascent Muslim community in Madinah, following discussions on the change of Qibla and preceding detailed rules about fasting, including exemptions, compensation, and the importance of supplicating during this sacred month. It emphasizes the continuity of this spiritual practice across previous nations, connecting the Muslim Ummah to a universal tradition of devotion.
educational_notes.theme_explanation: The central theme of this verse is the obligation of fasting (Sawm) for believers and its profound spiritual purpose. By stating that fasting was 'decreed upon you as it was decreed upon those before you,' Allah (SWT) highlights the universal wisdom and timeless nature of this act of worship. The ultimate goal, 'that you may become righteous' (لَعَلَّكُمْ تَتَّقُونَ), underscores that fasting is not merely abstaining from food and drink, but a means to cultivate Taqwa – God-consciousness, piety, and self-restraint, leading to a deeper connection with Allah and a more virtuous life.
educational_notes.surah_overview: Al-Baqarah (The Cow) is the longest surah in the Quran, comprising 286 verses, and was primarily revealed in Madinah. It serves as a foundational guide for the Muslim community, covering a vast array of topics essential for establishing an Islamic society. Juz 2 specifically encompasses verses 142-252 of Surah Al-Baqarah. This section addresses critical issues such as the change of Qibla (direction of prayer) from Jerusalem to Makkah, establishing a distinct identity for the Muslim Ummah. It also lays down fundamental laws regarding fasting (Sawm) during Ramadan, the pilgrimage (Hajj), financial dealings (prohibition of interest, encouragement of charity), marriage, divorce, and the prohibition of alcohol and gambling. The Juz also includes narratives of prophets like Musa (AS) and the Children of Israel, offering lessons from past communities for the guidance of the believers.
